page.title: 02MARSDEN ROCK.
page.content: Marsden Rock is a sea stack of magnesian limestone, which can be reached at low tide.It rises vertically from the sea bed to a height of 50m, and stands about 100m from the cliffs. For many years the rock has been battered by the sea and waves and has the appearance of a "triumphal arch" with a cavern carved out of the rock at sea level. On top of the rock a huge colony of sea-birds nest all year round, making this site the most important sea bird colony in over 100 miles of coastline from Yorkshire to the Farne Islands. Marsden Rock is now a Nature Centre run by the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds.
